title: Wild life conservation of sri lanka
description: Wildlife conservation in Sri Lanka is of paramount importance due to the country's rich biodiversity and unique ecosystems. Sri Lanka boasts a wide variety of flora and fauna, including several species that are endemic to the island. The government, in collaboration with various conservation organizations, has implemented several initiatives to protect and preserve the country's wildlife. National parks and wildlife sanctuaries, such as Yala National Park and Wilpattu National Park, play a crucial role in safeguarding the diverse habitats and species. These protected areas serve as havens for elephants, leopards, sloth bears, and a myriad of bird species, ensuring the survival of threatened and endangered animals.

Despite these efforts, wildlife conservation in Sri Lanka faces challenges such as habitat loss, human-wildlife conflict, and poaching. Rapid urbanization and agricultural expansion have led to habitat fragmentation, impacting the natural corridors for wildlife movement. The government and conservationists are actively working on mitigating these challenges through sustainable land-use planning and community engagement programs. By fostering awareness and involving local communities in conservation efforts, Sri Lanka aims to strike a balance between human development and the preservation of its unique and irreplaceable natural heritage.
